video.title: Learn Vue.js - Full Course for Beginners - 2019
video.description:
Learn to use Vue.js in this full tutorial course for beginners.
🚨 NEW version of this course: https://youtu.be/FXpIoQ_rT_c

Vue.js is an open-source JavaScript framework for building user interfaces and single-page applications.

💻 Code - Quiz App: https://github.com/gwenf/vue-quiz 
💻 Code - Pet App: https://github.com/gwenf/vue-adopt-pets

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
(0:32) Part 1:
⌨️ The Vue Instance
⌨️ Directives
⌨️ Methods
⌨️ Data-binding
⌨️ Events
⌨️ Filters
⌨️ Computed Properties
⌨️ Components
⌨️ Component Lifecycle

(35:33) Part 2:
⌨️ Vue-cli
⌨️ Vue devtools
⌨️ Props & Slots
⌨️ Making API calls
⌨️ Vue-router
⌨️ Vuex
⌨️ Unit Testing
⌨️ Recommended Resources

⭐️ Links: ⭐️
🔗 TheJaredWilcurt Twitch Channel: https://www.twitch.tv/thejaredwilcurt 
🔗 Sarah Drasner, Vue Animations: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LLnVLjpY6gE
🔗 Views on Vue podcast: https://devchat.tv/views-on-vue/ 
🔗 State of Vue.js Report: https://www.monterail.com/state-of-vuejs-report

✏ Course from Gwen Faraday. Check out her YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCxA99Yr6P_tZF9_BgtMGAWA

🐦 Gwen on Twitter: https://twitter.com/gwen_faraday 
📬 Email Gwen: gwenfaraday@pm.me

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

And subscribe for new videos on technology: https://youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=freecodecamp

topLevelComment.author: Michael Kiger - Avian Web Hosting
topLevelComment.text: Good example of Vue.js but I don't see it being  a 'full course' when it has no input or database to make the app/website fully functional. I would like to see more 'real world' tutorials that show apps that would be used in production. Apps that someone might pay a developer to 'develop'. Can we stop it with the 'Hello World' stuff that nobody would buy and do some mature marketable production apps?  I did look at the updated version... MUCH better! Seriously folks there have been ten thousand 'hello world' 'tutorials' past ten years. Let's consider that most adults don't live in a cartoon world and most developers no matter what level they are at want to create apps that someone would pay them to create. Apps that would actually be used in a real business. This means apps that have input with the front-end and connects to a database backend. Most of these 'tutorials' on YT are small pieces of apps that are not useful for much besides showing off on YT.

topLevelComment.author: coding husky
topLevelComment.text:
I swear I have to do this for every tutorial I go though... so for someone as unreasonable as me to do this under Windows 10; it's likely your adopt-pets app will fail to even create due to node-sass issues. Here's what I had to do to fix it:
- install Python 3.9 and 2.7 for Windows (yes, both, no idea why because 2.7 is required)
- set Windows environment variables to Python 2.7 (google it if you don't know how) and made sure my python  - - version command ran in node.js shell responded with 2.7
- opened node.js shell as admin (won't work otherwise!) and ran: npm install node-sass
- then ran:  npm install node-router
- lastly, ran: npm config set python python2 
Only then was I able to create the project. Hope this helps someone.

topLevelComment.author: pedro matias
topLevelComment.text:
And also, you must change your 'for loop' in the <b-list-group-item> like so:
 <b-list-group-item 
                    <b-list-group-item 

                    v-for="(answer, index) in shuffledAnswers" 
                    :key="index"
                    @click="selectedAnswer(index)"
                    :class="answerClass(index)"
                >
Otherwise, you won't be able to see the correct order for your answers being displayed

topLevelComment.author: Sugen
topLevelComment.text:
I do think while this is a good tutorial for practicing a working knowledge of Vuejs, I do think you have some instances where you don't really explain a lot of your work prior to some of the solutions you make. Take the correctIndex case at 1:32:00 you never covered what that object was prior to using it. You only do show this at 1:41:10 where you are color coding the correct answer from the incorrect answer. Not to mention that some of the errors you made while recording this video were pretty unnecessary and eat up a lot of time. I'm not sure if those mistakes were scripted in this video but its distracting nonetheless. Additionally in your early example about filters using jsfiddle, you basically rerecorded a section about filters twice without it really adding much to the discussion.

I think your editing could use some work since the flow of this video is a hot mess for people who are relatively new to SPA

topLevelComment.author: Sayeed Ahmed
topLevelComment.text:
Loved the tutorial so far!!
1:28:56
To handling shuffling, we could use lodash.shuffle() on the original answers array itself within computed block.
That way, the answers on screen are already shuffled and we wouldn't need to go around explicitly shuffling downstream and then also handle the edge case of 1st question not shuffling..
Something like this..
**********
computed: {
    answers() {
      let answers = [...this.currentQuestion.incorrect_answers]
      answers.push(this.currentQuestion.correct_answer)
      answers = _.shuffle(answers)
      return answers
    }
  },
***********

topLevelComment.text: Running "vue create" generates a directory (and subdirectories) with 24,255 files.  Why does a "single page app" require 24,255 files? Is the NPM model 1 big failure?  And talk about security hole.  How do I ensure that there is no virus in one of the 24,255 files?

replies.author: Jesse "Wazanator" Culver
replies.text:
That is one of the main issues with npm. Unless you want to read through all the files or pass them through a static code analysis tool (which you have to trust is going to catch anything malicious) you are trusting that not only is the package you pulled in clean but any packages that package is pulling is clean and so and so forth. Which is why you should be very careful about what packages you decide you need.


However this is a security issue for any package distribution network including any sources you have mounted in apt. You have to trust that there is enough people maintaining a package that nothing is going to slip through and if it does that it gets patched quickly.


Of course you can take the same approach with npm as you can with apt and self host a registry for your organization and dedicate individuals to checking patches/packages and pushing them through to your registry manually after passing review. That is of course pretty expensive in terms of man hours if you are wanting to make sure your packages are relatively up to date.

If you want the next button to be disabled before you press submit you can do the following: 



<b-button 
   @click="next" 
   variant="success"
   :disabled="selectedIndex === null || !answered"
   >Next
</b-button>


The same as the submit button except you use "!answered" instead of "answered".

topLevelComment.author: Rajath
topLevelComment.text:
I have been wondering about the integration of vuejs to with django. In any of the vuejs videos hardly does anyone speak of or explain about the functionalities of backend with vue.

For beginners like us it's really confusing. For example - vue already has a vue router and say we can even perform firebase within Vue. Now the question arises why/where does backend come into. Overall, it's a fantastically done tutorial!
